hadiths.english_translation: Khalaf ibn Tamim informed us, he said: I asked Ismail ibn Ibrahim ibn Muhajir about the birth of Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr, so he said: Indeed I questioned him about the matter you asked me about, so he informed me that he was born in the last three years of the caliphate of Uthman

narrators.name: Khalaf ibn Tamim
narrators.full_name: Khalaf ibn Tamim al-Wasiti

narrators.name: Ismail ibn Ibrahim
narrators.full_name: Ismail ibn Ibrahim ibn Muhajir al-Asadi
reliabilityIssues: transmission through questioning rather than direct narration

narrators.name: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr ibn Hani' al-Lakhmī

chainIssues: Transmission via questioning (saaltu) rather than direct narration term
Ambiguous connection between Ismail's questioning and Abd al-Malik's response

potential_issues.issue: Unusual transmission terminology - questioning rather than standard narration
potential_issues.impact: The use of 'I asked' (سَأَلْتُ) instead of standard transmission terms like haddathana or akhbarana introduces ambiguity about whether this represents direct transmission or mere inquiry

potential_issues.issue: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr narrates about his own birth year
potential_issues.impact: While this is acceptable (personal biographical information), it represents a first-person biographical report rather than a hadith report

Topics: Birth date of Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr
Biographical information about dates during Uthman's caliphate

hadiths.english_translation: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Yunus informed us, from Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash, he said: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr said to me one day while I was with him: 'There have passed upon me one hundred and three years'. He said: And Sufyan ibn Uyaynah said: 'They were the two great ones of the people of Kufa at that time - this one is a son of one hundred, and this one is a son of one hundred - meaning Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr and Ziad ibn Ilaqah'. Sufyan said: And I heard Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr saying: 'By Allah, indeed I narrate the hadith and I do not leave a single letter from it'

narrators.name: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Yunus
narrators.full_name: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Yunus al-'Ijli

narrators.name: Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash
narrators.full_name: Abu Bakr Suleiman ibn Ayyash al-Dhaili
reliabilityIssues: reported to have weak memory in later years

narrators.name: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr ibn Hani' al-Lakhmī

chainIssues: Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash is known for tadlis (hiding weak transmission links)
Use of 'an (عَنْ) from Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash with a mudallis narrator requires caution
The hadith contains embedded accounts from other narrators (Sufyan ibn Uyaynah) which creates multiple transmission paths

potential_issues.issue: Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash reported to practice tadlis (deliberate hiding of transmission links)
potential_issues.impact: The use of 'an (عَنْ) by this narrator introduces ambiguity about whether he heard this directly or through intermediaries. However, Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash is generally considered reliable (Saduq), and given the biographical nature of the report, the tadlis concern is reduced

potential_issues.issue: Embedded reports within the hadith from Sufyan ibn Uyaynah
potential_issues.impact: The hadith contains secondary reports attributed to Sufyan ibn Uyaynah ('He said' - قَالَ), which creates a complex narrative structure with multiple authority levels

potential_issues.issue: Biographical report about age and memory of Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr
potential_issues.impact: This is a first-person biographical statement about the narrator's age (100+ years) and his reliability in transmission, which serves as a character attestation

Topics: Age of Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr - reported as over one hundred years
Biographical information about prominent Kufa scholars
Character testimony about Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr's precision in hadith transmission
Comparison of Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr and Ziad ibn Ilaqah as major Kufa scholars

hadiths.english_translation: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Yunus informed us, he said: Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash narrated to us, he said: Abu Ishaq said to us: 'Question Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr and Simak ibn Harb, though Simak did not have all of that - he was only a man of hadiths'. They said: And Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr served as judge in Kufa before al-Sha'bi, and he was given the epithet 'the Egyptian', and he died in Kufa in Dhu al-Hijjah in the year one hundred and thirty-six. He said: And al-Haytham ibn Adi said: I was present at his funeral procession. He said: And it was narrated to me from Hafs ibn Ghiyath that he said: I saw Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr as an old man, sitting on a chair, anointing himself from his forehead to his feet

narrators.name: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Yunus
narrators.full_name: Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Yunus al-'Ijli

narrators.name: Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash
narrators.full_name: Abu Bakr Suleiman ibn Ayyash al-Dhaili

narrators.name: Abu Ishaq al-Subai'i
narrators.full_name: Amr ibn Abdullah ibn Ubaid al-Hamadani, known as Abu Ishaq al-Subai'i

narrators.name: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr ibn Hani' al-Lakhmī

chainIssues: Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash using both 'an (عَنْ) and haddathana (حَدَّثَنَا) in different parts suggests the compiler mixed sources
Complex narrative structure with multiple embedded reports (al-Haytham ibn Adi, Hafs ibn Ghiyath)
The hadith contains editorial transitions ('They said' - قَالُوا) indicating compilation of multiple accounts

potential_issues.issue: Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash is known for tadlis and weak memory in later years
potential_issues.impact: While Abu Bakr ibn Ayyash is graded as Saduq, his practice of tadlis and memory weakness mean his reports require caution. However, for biographical information, this is less critical than for Quranic or prophetic hadiths

potential_issues.issue: Complex embedded narratives and multiple transmission layers
potential_issues.impact: The hadith contains reports within reports - al-Haytham ibn Adi's statement about attending the funeral, and Hafs ibn Ghiyath's observation of Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr. These sub-reports do not have explicit transmission chains documented

potential_issues.issue: Biographical compilation rather than direct transmission
potential_issues.impact: This appears to be a compiled biographical entry drawing from multiple sources and accounts about Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr's life, death, and character rather than a traditional hadith report

potential_issues.issue: Abu Ishaq al-Subai'i reporting about questioning Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr
potential_issues.impact: While Abu Ishaq is reliable, his recommendation to question Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr is conditional and comparative with Simak ibn Harb, suggesting selective use of sources

Topics: Biographical compilation about Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr
His appointment as judge in Kufa before al-Sha'bi
His epithet 'the Egyptian'
Date and location of death in 136 AH
Character testimony and physical description of Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr in old age
His reliability and prominence among Kufa scholars

hadiths.english_translation: He died in the year one hundred and twenty-two when Zaid ibn Ali was killed in Kufa. And Abu Nu'aym said: Zaid was killed on the Day of Ashura in that year. And Salamah was prolific in hadith transmission

hadiths.english_translation: Wakee' informed us, from Sufyan, from Qais ibn Muslim Abu Amr al-Bijli, he said: And I heard Abu Nu'aym al-Fadl ibn Dukain, he said: Qais ibn Muslim died in the year one hundred and twenty in Kufa, and he was reliable, firmly established, and possessed good hadith

potential_issues.issue: Complex nested transmission structure
